questions.question: A rectangle has a length of 11 centimeters and a width of 4 centimeters. What is the area, in square centimeters, of the rectangle?
questions.explanation: The area of a rectangle is <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>l</mi><mi>w</mi></math>. Substituting <math><mi>l</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math> and <math><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> gives <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>44</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For rectangles, multiply length by width; do not add them.

questions.question: A right circular cylinder has radius <math><mn>3</mn></math> inches and height <math><mn>5</mn></math> inches. What is the volume, in terms of <math><mi>π</mi></math>, of the cylinder?
questions.explanation: The volume of a cylinder is <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>h</mi></math>. With <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> and <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><msup><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>45</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For cylinders, remember the radius is squared in <math><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>h</mi></math>.

questions.question: A rectangular prism has dimensions 7 meters by 4 meters by 2 meters. What is the volume, in cubic meters, of the prism?
questions.explanation: The volume of a rectangular prism is <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>l</mi><mi>w</mi><mi>h</mi></math>. Substituting gives <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>56</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Multiply all three dimensions for prism volume; track units as cubic.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='260' viewBox='0 0 420 260' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='260' fill='white'/><path d='M 80 200 L 320 200 L 80 80 Z' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><rect x='80' y='180' width='20' height='20' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='190' y='220' font-size='16'>12</text><text x='45' y='145' font-size='16'>7</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Right triangle with base labeled 12 and height labeled 7.
questions.question: The figure shows a right triangle. What is the area of the triangle? Enter your answer as an integer.
questions.explanation: The area of a triangle is <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>b</mi><mi>h</mi></math>. Using <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> and <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>, <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>42</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For right triangles, the perpendicular legs are the base and height.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='260' viewBox='0 0 420 260' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='260' fill='white'/><path d='M 90 190 L 330 190 L 290 80 L 130 80 Z' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='200' y='215' font-size='16'>18</text><text x='200' y='70' font-size='16'>10</text><line x1='130' y1='80' x2='130' y2='190' stroke='black' stroke-dasharray='6,6' stroke-width='2'/><text x='95' y='140' font-size='16'>8</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Trapezoid with bases labeled 18 and 10 and a dashed height labeled 8.
questions.question: The figure shows a trapezoid with parallel bases of lengths 18 and 10 and height 8. What is the area, in square units, of the trapezoid?
questions.explanation: The area of a trapezoid is <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>b</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>)</mo><mi>h</mi></math>. Substituting <math><msub><mi>b</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></math>, <math><msub><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>, and <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math> gives <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>112</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For trapezoids, average the two bases, then multiply by the height.

questions.question: A right circular cylinder has volume <math><mn>200</mn><mi>π</mi></math> cubic centimeters and height 8 centimeters. What is the radius, in centimeters, of the base of the cylinder?
questions.explanation: Use <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>h</mi></math>. Substitute <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>200</mn><mi>π</mi></math> and <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>: <math><mn>200</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Divide by <math><mn>8</mn><mi>π</mi></math> to get <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>, so <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Cancel <math><mi>π</mi></math> early and solve for <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> before taking a square root.

questions.question: A cube has surface area 486 square centimeters. What is the volume of the cube, in cubic centimeters? Enter your answer as an integer.
questions.explanation: A cube with side length <math><mi>s</mi></math> has surface area <math><mn>6</mn><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. So <math><mn>6</mn><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>486</mn></math>, which gives <math><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>81</mn></math> and <math><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. The volume is <math><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>9</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>729</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize cube formulas: surface area <math><mn>6</mn><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> and volume <math><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></math>.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='280' viewBox='0 0 420 280' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='280' fill='white'/><path d='M 50 50 L 50 225 L 350 225 L 350 150 L 200 150 L 200 50 Z' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='35' y='145' font-size='16' font-family='serif' text-anchor='end'>7</text><text x='200' y='245' font-size='16' font-family='serif' text-anchor='middle'>12</text><text x='210' y='100' font-size='16' font-family='serif' text-anchor='start'>4</text><text x='275' y='145' font-size='16' font-family='serif' text-anchor='middle'>6</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: An L-shaped polygon. The left vertical side is labeled 7, and the bottom horizontal side is labeled 12. The re-entrant corner (the 'cutout' section) has a vertical edge labeled 4 and a horizontal edge labeled 6.
questions.question: The figure shows an L-shaped region. The outer rectangle is 12 units by 7 units, and a 6-by-4 rectangle is removed from one corner as shown. What is the area, in square units, of the L-shaped region?
questions.explanation: Compute the area of the large rectangle and subtract the area of the removed rectangle. The large rectangle has an area of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>12</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>84</mn></math>. The removed rectangle has an area of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>6</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn></math>. The remaining area is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>84</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>24</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math>. Therefore the area is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>60</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='280' viewBox='0 0 420 280' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='280' fill='white'/><rect x='50' y='50' width='300' height='175' fill='none' stroke='gray' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><path d='M 50 50 L 50 225 L 350 225 L 350 150 L 200 150 L 200 50 Z' fill='#e0f0ff' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><rect x='200' y='50' width='150' height='100' fill='#ffcccc' opacity='0.5' stroke='red' stroke-dasharray='4'/><text x='275' y='100' font-size='14' fill='red' text-anchor='middle'>Removed: 6×4 = 24</text><text x='125' y='150' font-size='16' fill='blue' text-anchor='middle'>Total Area = 84 - 24 = 60</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The diagram shows the full 12x7 rectangle with the 6x4 removed corner highlighted in red. The L-shaped region is shaded blue, illustrating the subtraction method.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For composite figures, break the shape into simpler rectangles or visualize the full bounding box and subtract the missing areas.

questions.question: A square has area 81 square inches. A second square has side length that is 2 times the side length of the first square. What is the area, in square inches, of the second square?
questions.explanation: If side length scales by a factor of <math><mn>2</mn></math>, area scales by a factor of <math><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. So the new area is <math><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>81</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>324</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Scaling a length by <math><mi>k</mi></math> scales area by <math><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.

questions.question: A right square pyramid has base side length 6 centimeters and height 10 centimeters. What is the volume, in cubic centimeters, of the pyramid? Enter your answer as an integer.
questions.explanation: The volume of a pyramid is <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>B</mi><mi>h</mi></math>, where <math><mi>B</mi></math> is the base area. The base is a square with area <math><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>6</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>360</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>120</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For pyramids and cones, include the <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> factor.

questions.question: A sphere of radius 4 is inscribed in a cube so that the sphere is tangent to all 6 faces of the cube. What is the difference between the volume of the cube and the volume of the sphere?
questions.explanation: If a sphere of radius <math><mn>4</mn></math> is tangent to all faces of a cube, the cube’s side length equals the sphere’s diameter, <math><mn>8</mn></math>. So the cube volume is <math><msup><mn>8</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>512</mn></math>. The sphere volume is <math><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi><msup><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>64</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>256</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi></math>. The difference is <math><mn>512</mn><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>256</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For inscribed solids, relate key dimensions first (here: side = diameter).

questions.question: A right circular cone has height 12 and radius 5. What is the total surface area of the cone, in square units?
questions.explanation: Total surface area equals base area plus lateral area: <math><mi>S</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>l</mi></math>, where <math><mi>l</mi></math> is slant height. Compute <math><mi>l</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><msup><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>144</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>25</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>169</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>S</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>65</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For cone surface area, find slant height using the Pythagorean theorem.

questions.question: A right circular cylinder has radius <math><mi>r</mi></math> and height <math><mi>h</mi></math>. A second cylinder has radius <math><mn>1.2</mn><mi>r</mi></math> and height <math><mn>0.8</mn><mi>h</mi></math>. The volume of the second cylinder is what multiple of the volume of the first cylinder?
questions.explanation: Cylinder volume is <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>h</mi></math>. The scale factor for radius is <math><mn>1.2</mn></math>, so <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> scales by <math><msup><mn>1.2</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>1.44</mn></math>. Height scales by <math><mn>0.8</mn></math>. Therefore the volume scales by <math><mn>1.44</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>1.152</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In volume formulas, any radius change is squared; combine multiplicative factors.

questions.question: A metal block is a rectangular prism with dimensions 2 cm by 3 cm by 5 cm. The density of the metal is 7.8 grams per cubic centimeter. What is the mass, in grams, of the block?
questions.explanation: First find volume: <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></math> cubic centimeters. Mass equals density times volume: <math><mn>7.8</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>234</mn></math> grams.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When density is given, compute volume first, then multiply.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><path d='M 110 180 L 290 180 L 290 105 L 110 105 Z' fill='#f0f0f0' stroke='none'/><path d='M 290 180 L 230 220 L 230 145 L 290 105 Z' fill='#e0e0e0' stroke='none'/><path d='M 50 220 L 230 220 L 290 180 L 110 180 Z' fill='#d0d0d0' stroke='none'/><line x1='110' y1='105' x2='110' y2='180' stroke='black' stroke-dasharray='4'/><line x1='110' y1='180' x2='290' y2='180' stroke='black' stroke-dasharray='4'/><line x1='110' y1='180' x2='50' y2='220' stroke='black' stroke-dasharray='4'/><rect x='50' y='145' width='180' height='75' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='145' x2='110' y2='105' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='230' y1='145' x2='290' y2='105' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='110' y1='105' x2='290' y2='105' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='290' y1='105' x2='290' y2='180' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='290' y1='180' x2='230' y2='220' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='140' y='240' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>12 (Length)</text><text x='270' y='210' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>8 (Width)</text><text x='30' y='190' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>5 (Height)</text><text x='150' y='130' font-size='12' fill='blue' font-style='italic'>Open Top</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A 3D rectangular box with an open top. The length of the base is 12, the width (depth) is 8, and the height is 5. The interior is shaded to indicate depth.
questions.question: An open-top rectangular box has a base that is 12 units by 8 units and a height of 5 units. What is the surface area of the box, in square units?
questions.explanation:
The surface area of an open-top box includes the base and the four side faces, but not the top cover. 
1. Base area: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>12</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>96</mn></math>.
2. Front and Back faces: Two faces of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>12</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Calculation: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>60</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>120</mn></math>.
3. Left and Right faces: Two faces of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>8</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Calculation: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn></math>.
Total surface area: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>96</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>120</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>80</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>296</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><rect x='140' y='110' width='120' height='80' fill='#d0d0d0' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='200' y='155' text-anchor='middle' font-size='12'>Base</text><text x='200' y='170' text-anchor='middle' font-size='10'>12 x 8 = 96</text><rect x='140' y='60' width='120' height='50' fill='#e0e0e0' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='200' y='85' text-anchor='middle' font-size='10'>Back: 12x5=60</text><rect x='140' y='190' width='120' height='50' fill='#e0e0e0' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='200' y='220' text-anchor='middle' font-size='10'>Front: 12x5=60</text><rect x='90' y='110' width='50' height='80' fill='#e0e0e0' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='115' y='155' text-anchor='middle' font-size='10' transform='rotate(-90 115,155)'>Side: 8x5=40</text><rect x='260' y='110' width='50' height='80' fill='#e0e0e0' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='285' y='155' text-anchor='middle' font-size='10' transform='rotate(90 285,155)'>Side: 8x5=40</text><line x1='140' y1='50' x2='260' y2='50' stroke='red' stroke-dasharray='4'/><text x='200' y='40' text-anchor='middle' fill='red' font-size='12'>Top Face Missing</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: A 'net' diagram of the box showing the flattened surfaces. It displays the central base (12x8) and four surrounding rectangles representing the sides (12x5 and 8x5). The top face is explicitly marked as missing to illustrate why it is excluded from the area calculation.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For open-top boxes, calculate the area of the base and add the lateral area (the four sides), but do not include the area of the 'lid' (top face).

questions.question: A sphere has volume <math><mfrac><mn>32</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi></math> cubic units. What is the radius of the sphere? Enter your answer as an integer.
questions.explanation: Use <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></math>. Set <math><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>32</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi></math>. Cancel <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi></math> on both sides to get <math><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn></math>, so <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math> and <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></math> before taking a cube root on sphere volume problems.

questions.question: A rectangular prism has length <math><mi>x</mi></math>, width <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, and height 3. The volume of the prism is 60. What is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Volume is <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>l</mi><mi>w</mi><mi>h</mi></math>, so <math><mn>60</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Divide by 3: <math><mn>20</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Then <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Factoring gives <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, so the positive solution is <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Translate a volume statement into an equation, then solve for the dimension.

questions.question: A right circular cylinder has height 9 and lateral surface area <math><mn>108</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. What is the radius of the cylinder? Enter your answer as an integer.
questions.explanation: Lateral surface area of a cylinder is <math><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>h</mi></math>. Substitute <math><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>108</mn><mi>π</mi></math> and <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>: <math><mn>108</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Cancel <math><mi>π</mi></math> and divide by 18 to get <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Differentiate between lateral area <math><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>h</mi></math> and total surface area.

questions.question: A solid cube has side length 10. A cylindrical hole of radius 3 is drilled straight through the cube from one face to the opposite face. What is the volume of the remaining solid?
questions.explanation: The cube volume is <math><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>1000</mn></math>. The drilled hole is a cylinder with radius <math><mn>3</mn></math> and height <math><mn>10</mn></math>. Cylinder volume: <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>90</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. Remaining volume is <math><mn>1000</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>90</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Subtract the removed volume from the original, and match units carefully.

questions.question: Two concentric circles have radii 9 and 5. What is the area of the region between the circles?
questions.explanation: The area of an annulus is the difference of circle areas: <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mn>9</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Compute: <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>81</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>56</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For concentric-circle regions, subtract areas using <math><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.
